content: If you do any work tied to roadways, bridges, traffic structures, or public infrastructure, you already know the biggest risk isn‚Äôt ‚Äúcan we weld it?‚Äù‚Äîit‚Äôs will it pass inspection and stay compliant with DOT specs. This guide breaks down how AWS D1.1 typically shows up on DOT jobs, when DOT work actually requires bridge-specific code (AWS D1.5), and what documentation + execution standards are most often expected in the field. For DOT and infrastructure support in Hampton Roads and surrounding regions, see our DOT page here: Kings Mobile Welding ‚Äì DOT & Infrastructure ‚Üí https://www.kingsmobilewelding.com/industries/DOT-Infrastructure/ First: DOT welding isn‚Äôt ‚Äúone code‚Äù Most DOT projects are governed by a stack of requirements: Contract documents (plans/specs, special provisions, notes) State DOT standard specs (ex: VDOT specs for Virginia projects) National references (AASHTO specs and AWS structural welding codes) Project QC/QA and inspection requirements On bridges and primary structural steel, DOT work commonly points to the AASHTO/AWS Bridge Welding Code (AWS D1.5) rather than AWS D1.1. The FHWA‚Äôs Bridge Welding Reference Manual specifically explains how highway structures rely on AASHTO/AWS D1.5 and how it relates to AWS D1.1. Bottom line: AWS D1.1 is the general ‚Äústructural steel‚Äù code used across many industries. AWS D1.5 is the bridge-focused code used for welded bridges/components designed to AASHTO/AREMA requirements. And at the federal level, FHWA regulations list standards that include AASHTO/AWS D1.5 and AWS D1.4 (rebar) among the recognized references for highway-related standards. Where AWS D1.1 shows up on DOT projects Even when the project is ‚ÄúDOT,‚Äù not everything is bridge code. AWS D1.1 is commonly used for: Highway-related structural steel that is not part of a bridge superstructure (project-specific‚Äîalways verify) Miscellaneous steel packages on DOT jobs Temporary works and support frames (if allowed by specs) Field modifications/repairs to structural items that are governed by D1.1 in the contract Fabrication or site welding on structures that fall under general structural steel requirements Also, DOT work often involves other AWS codes depending on the material: AWS D1.4 is used for reinforcing steel welding when permitted by the design/specs. When it‚Äôs NOT AWS D1.1: bridge work often triggers AWS D1.5 If you‚Äôre welding on: bridge girders / bridge components bridge splices structural bridge repairs governed by bridge specs bridge fabrication requirements called out in DOT documents ‚Ä¶you‚Äôll very often be under AWS D1.5, not D1.1. DOT training/inspection materials commonly reference AASHTO/AWS D1.5 for bridge welding conformance. Tip: The fastest way to get burned on DOT work is assuming ‚ÄúAWS D1.1 certified‚Äù automatically equals ‚Äúbridge compliant.‚Äù D1.1 is a big deal‚Äîbut bridge specs can be different (procedures, acceptance criteria, inspector expectations, etc.). The DOT inspection mindset: ‚ÄúShow me the paperwork, then show me the weld‚Äù On DOT jobs, the weld itself is only half the battle. The other half is proving you had control of: 1) Welding procedures: WPS (and sometimes PQR) A WPS (Welding Procedure Specification) is the document the welder follows to produce code-compliant welds. In AWS D1.1, many contractors use prequalified WPS (when the joint details, process, base metal group, filler, etc. meet the code‚Äôs prequalification limits). If you don‚Äôt meet prequal rules, you typically need procedure qualification testing (a PQR) to prove the procedure works. What inspectors/GCs commonly want on DOT work: The WPS on site (current revision, signed, legible) Proof the procedure is prequalified or qualified by testing (as required) 2) Welder performance qualification (WPQ) Even with a solid WPS, DOT/GCs will typically require proof the welder is qualified for: the process (SMAW/FCAW/GMAW, etc.) the position (1G/2G/3G/4G‚Ä¶) the joint type and thickness range (per code/spec) 3) Material and filler control Expect attention to: base metal identification (including coatings like galvanizing, when applicable) electrode/filler classification and storage/conditioning as required by project specs preheat/interpass requirements as written in the WPS (and sometimes contract notes) 4) Inspection + acceptance criteria DOT work frequently requires a documented inspection pathway (visual inspection always, and NDT when specified). The ‚Äúacceptance‚Äù criteria will be whatever the contract cites (D1.1 vs D1.5 vs special provisions). What ‚ÄúAWS D1.1 explained‚Äù means in the field (plain English) Here‚Äôs the practical way to think about AWS D1.1 on real jobs: D1.1 tells you how to make structural welds that are acceptable under the code (procedures, qualification, workmanship, inspection). You still have to follow the job‚Äôs drawings and spec notes (D1.1 doesn‚Äôt override project requirements). Your WPS is the rulebook your welder actually follows on the jobsite. title: Best Welding Practices for Coastal Environments: Fighting Rust & Corrosion
categories: Welding & Fabrication, Coastal & Marine Projects, Structural Steel, Maintenance & Repairs, Safety & Best Practices

content: Welding in coastal regions brings unique challenges‚Äîsalt air, high humidity, and constant exposure to moisture can wreak havoc on metal structures. At Kings Mobile Welding, we specialize in on-site AWS D1.1-certified welding and fabrication across Hampton Roads and the surrounding areas, so we know firsthand how to combat corrosion in harsh coastal environments. Why Coastal Environments Are So Tough on Metal Steel and aluminum structures near the ocean are constantly exposed to salt-laden air, which accelerates oxidation and pitting corrosion. According to Red-D-Arc, salt particles carry chlorides that act as electrolytes, attacking weld joints faster than inland conditions. Additionally, TWI Global explains that weld metal and heat-affected zones (HAZ) can develop different microstructures than the base metal, leading to localized corrosion at the weld itself. Combined with high humidity and fluctuating wet/dry cycles, this creates a perfect storm for metal deterioration. Best Practices for Welding in Coastal Environments 1. Choose the Right Materials Opt for marine-grade stainless steel (316L or duplex) for superior chloride resistance. For carbon steel, ensure a robust coating and maintenance plan is in place. Avoid dissimilar metal contact to reduce galvanic corrosion (see Nature.com). 2. Design Welds for Drainage & Access Coastal structures benefit from continuous welds, smooth contours, and designs that prevent water trapping. The Whole Building Design Guide (WBDG) recommends avoiding skip welds and lap joints that collect saltwater. Good weld geometry also allows for even coating coverage. 3. Use Proper Welding Techniques Stick with low-hydrogen processes to minimize cracking. Thoroughly clean the weld zone before and after welding to remove spatter and contaminants. Grind and polish weld beads so coatings adhere uniformly. Ensure complete fusion and sound weld quality‚Äîdefects quickly become corrosion points. 4. Apply Marine-Grade Coatings Immediately after welding and cleaning, use epoxy primers, zinc-rich coatings, or galvanizing for protection. As Caltrans Corrosion Guidelines emphasize, the coating must maintain even thickness over welds, edges, and corners‚Äîthin or skipped areas lead to early failure. For extreme salt exposure (such as docks, barges, or shipyard work), consider cathodic protection systems to further slow corrosion. 5. Inspect and Maintain Regularly Routine inspections are essential. Look for rust bleed-through, coating blistering, or crevice corrosion near welds. According to TWI Global, regular maintenance and NDT inspections extend service life dramatically.
